name: MistralAIModel

input.content:
In freecad I want to have a circle but only for reference not to actually be a circle but just so I can line up other lines to make a hexagon for example.
How do I do that?

output:
In FreeCAD, you can use the "Construction" geometry type to create reference shapes that won't be included in the final model. Here's how to create a reference circle:

1. Switch to the Draft Workbench if you're not already in it. You can do this by clicking on "Draft" in the Workbench toolbar or by going to "View" > "Workbenches" > "Draft" in the menu bar.

2. Click on the "Draft" dropdown menu in the toolbar, then go to "Utility" > "Construction". This will enable the construction mode for your next shape.

3. Now, you can create your reference circle. Click on the "Draft" dropdown menu again, then go to "Circle" > "Center and radius".

4. Click on the screen to define the center of the circle, then move your mouse to set the radius and click again to create the circle.

Now you have a reference circle that you can use to line up other shapes. The circle won't be included in the final model, but it will still be visible in the sketch to help guide your design.

name: WordEvaluator
input:

2. Click on the "Draft" dropdown menu in the toolbar, then go to "Utility" > "Construction". This will enable the construction mode for your next shape.

3. Now, you can create your reference circle. Click on the "Draft" dropdown menu again, then go to "Circle" > "Center and radius".

4. Click on the screen to define the center of the circle, then move your mouse to set the radius and click again to create the circle.

Now you have a reference circle that you can use to line up other shapes. The circle won't be included in the final model, but it will still be visible in the sketch to help guide your design.
